These DFIs exited the project in 2016 at the time that Addax sold the project to Sunbird.;Rothonka#Man-man#Romaro#Worreyhema#Mara#Roportor#Chain Bundu#Rothun#Maronko#Lungi Acre#Yainkasa#Mampa#Manewa#Mataro#Madora#Komrabai Makay#Masethleh#Mayaingbain#Robala#Mamudu#Laminaya#Kiamp Kakolo#Worreh Wanda#Tiama#;;Mara, Makari and Bombali Sebora chiefdoms in Bombali district.;Community traditional or customary rights recognized by government;;Limited consultation;Since Sunbird took over the operations from Addax in 2016 stakeholder engagement is slowly diminishing and only happens when the company sees its own benefit. The community claims that the land agreement was not discussed entirely and the community was not given the opportunity for free and prior informed consent regarding some of the clauses in the lease agreement (another source states that the draft land lease was disclosed to the community for one year in order to obtain FPIC). ABSL invented a legal instrument, the so called Acknowledgement Agreements (AA). AAs are additional agreements that were signed with each landowning family when their land was about to be used for the project. ABSL hired a consultant specialised on Geographic Information Systems (GIS) that would map the land together with the owners. AAs include an additional rent, which is paid directly to the land owner. AAs include a formal declaration of support for the project and a recognition of the Land Lease Agreement (LLA) signed by the paramount chiefs. A 2020 report claims that communication still remains a problem because formats like village level community meetings or multistakeholder meetings are no longer held regularly. As a result people are not adequately informed about the company and even left out. Information passed on to few representatives at meetings conducted by Sunbird is failing to trickle down to communities. Renegotiated land lease agreements were signed in 2019 between landowners represented by the chiefdom councils and the company. however, the agreement was rushed through by the company and signed without the consent of communities, landowners or land users. The final agreement is still not available to communities or the public.;Rejection;Landowners feel that they have no choice but to accept the project as it was forced upon them by the president. The project was initially seen as an extension of the president’s wishes and was not to be rejected by local people. Renegotiated land lease agreements were signed in 2019 between landowners represented by the chiefdom councils and the company. however, the agreement was rushed through by the company and signed without the consent of communities, landowners or land users. The final agreement is still not available to communities or the public.;Yes;Space for expressing issues is shrinking under Sunbird majority ownership. column1: Despite being SA 8000-certified since 2001—an international standard for decent labor practices—Sumifru has been repeatedly accused of serious labor and human rights violations. These include excessive working hours
column2: poor wages
column3: non-payment of benefits
column4: illegal labor-only contracting
column5: and efforts to suppress union activities. The company has attempted to impose exploitative piece-rate wage schemes and has evaded accountability for numerous legal violations. It was even listed by DOLE among the top 20 companies engaged in prohibited labor practices.

column1: [Exposure to Chemicals and other Health Hazards]
Sumifru
column2: though certified under Global G.A.P. standards meant to ensure safe
column3: environmentally responsible farming and worker protection
column4: has been accused of exposing its workers to hazardous chemicals without adequate safety measures. Workers report health issues such as vision loss
column5: respiratory problems
column6: skin diseases
column7: and infertility due to pesticide exposure and lack of proper PPE—often having to purchase protective gear with their own money. The company reportedly provides such equipment only once a year.

column1: [Harrassment
column2: Intimidation
column3: Union Busting]

column1: After launching a strike on October 1
column3: over demands for a CBA
column4: regularization
column5: and better wages
column6: NAMASUFA union members faced escalating harassment
column7: including house raids
column8: beatings
column9: red-tagging
column10: and pressure to falsely certify Sumifru’s labor compliance.

column1: The most critical incident occurred on October 11
column2: when combined forces from the AFP’s 66th IB
column3: PNP
column4: and hired goons violently dispersed strike camps at five packing plants. Unionists were beaten
column5: threatened at gunpoint
column6: and several leaders were arrested and assaulted before being released. The most serious injury was sustained by the PP 250 Union President
column7: who vomited blood
column8: had facial injuries
column9: and experienced difficulty walking and speaking. Despite a court dismissal of Sumifru’s TRO petition
column10: the violent dispersal pushed through
column11: underscoring the use of force to suppress the strike.

column1: [Death Threats
column2: Slay Attempts
column3: and Murders]

column1: NAMASUFA union leaders and members in Compostela Valley have faced ongoing violence and threats. After filing a labor claim in 2005
column2: union chair Vicente Barrios and others were ambushed in 2006
column3: resulting in injuries and the death of member Gerson Lastimoso. In October 2018
column4: Danny Boy Bautista was shot dead
column5: becoming the second slain union member. Weeks later
column6: another member
column7: Jerry Alicante
column8: survived a shooting but was injured.

column7: the NAMASUFA union denounced the program as a sham
column8: stating that none of their leaders received assistance and that their members were not displaced but had only ceased work due to an ongoing labor dispute. Citing an NLRC reinstatement order from August 6
column10: NAMASUFA accused Sumifru and the government of using the program to mislead the public and weaken workers' resolve to assert their rights.;On June 9

column13: and Sumifru (Philippines) Corp. through a conciliation-mediation facilitated by DOLE Region XI. Represented by their counsel under the Single Entry Approach (SEnA)
column14: the workers
column15: led by NAMASUFA PP 90 leader Vicente Barrios
column16: opted to receive separation pay instead of reinstatement. This decision was anchored on a Supreme Court ruling recognizing them as regular employees of Sumifru. All 92 workers voluntarily accepted their separation pay and cash bonuses
column17: which were distributed in the presence of labor officials.;;;;;"Nagkahiusang Mamumuo sa Suyapa Farm (NAMASUFA-NAFLU-KMU)

column1: Sumifru workers in Compostela Valley organized their first local unions from their packing plant units in the mid-2000s
column2: to assert their right for better wages and working conditions. In August 2018
column3: 8 local unions of Sumifru workers consolidated into one union under NAMASUFA
column4: a 900-member union of rank-and-file workers in 8 packing plants at the time.

column1: Although the Supreme Court upheld the Department of Labor and Employment’s (DOLE) July 2008 order granting NAMASUFA’s petition for certification as the Sole and Exclusive Bargaining Agent (SEBA)
column2: Sumifru refused to recognize the union. The company claimed the union’s consolidation was illegal—despite the Supreme Court’s ruling—and argued that the workers were employed not by Sumifru but by A2Y Contracting Services
column3: a third-party manpower agency it had hired.

column1: Because of low wages
column2: lack of benefits
column3: exposure to hazardous working conditions and Sumifru’s refusal to recognise the workers as its employees
column4: NAMASUFA launched a strike on 10 October 2018. The fight for regularisation of the Sumifru workers was brought to the capital city of Manila after union workers were dismissed from their jobs and the violent dispersal of their strike camp on 10 October 2018. In 2019
column5: a Writ of Execution on Return- to-Work Order was issued by the National Labour Relations Commission (NLRC) in favour of the striking workers.

column8: women workers from Sumifru including a young woman researcher
column9: mentor and coresearchers from the Women Studies and Resource Center (WSRC) conducted the Feminist Participatory Action Research (FPAR). The body clock activity
column10: as well as focus group discussions and surveys were used to document the impacts of labour contractualisation and dangerous working conditions that women workers suffer from in the Sumifru banana packing plants in Davao de Oro.

column1: [FPAR Findings]
1. Lack of job security
- Even long-term workers fear dismissal or non-renewal of contracts for not meeting production quotas.
- Backup workers—mostly women—face the greatest uncertainty
column2: often going home without work or pay due to a first-come
column3: first-served selection process.

column1: 2. Unsafe working conditions
column2: long working hours
column3: and low wages.

column1: - ILO standards are poorly enforced. PPE use is only required during inspections
column2: and the plants have poor ventilation.

column1: - Exposure to agrochemicals leads to health issues like nausea and breathing difficulties.
- Women work 12–20 hours a day with minimal breaks and can finish as late as 2:00 AM
column2: returning at 6:00 AM especially during peak seasons.

column1: - Daily wages average PHP 365 (~USD 7)
column2: while Sumifru reportedly earns PHP 38 million (~USD 760
column3: 000) daily.

column1: 3. Unaddressed burden of unpaid care work
- Despite grueling shifts
column2: women still shoulder housework on weekends.

column1: - The COVID-19 pandemic intensified this burden
column2: as women had to supervise their children's distance learning
column3: often without adequate educational backgrounds themselves.

column1: 4. Lack of maternity benefits and social protection
- Maternity leave and other benefits guaranteed under RA 11210 are denied.
- Pregnant women work up to their due dates
column2: and retirement or separation benefits are not provided by Sumifru or its service providers.

column1: 5. Use of militarism to break the strike and union.
- State forces violently dispersed strike camps
column2: injuring women and threatening their safety and homes.

column1: - Family members were also threatened
column2: causing psychological trauma and coercing workers to abandon union activities.

column1: - Robilina Limo
column2: four-month pregnant worker and union member was kicked in upper abdomen during the violent dispersal in Packing Plant 115.

column1: The conflict involving Plantations du Haut Penja (PHP) centers on allegations of misconduct
column2: including tax evasion and labor rights violations on its plantations in Cameroon. The situation escalated when Paul Eric Kingue
column3: the former mayor of Njombé-Penja
column4: exposed these practices and was subsequently arrested in 2008 on charges believed to be fabricated. Various organizations
column5: such as Transparency International
column6: have called for a review of the judicial process
column7: noting severe flaws in the trial. In 2024
column8: the UN declared Kingue's arrest arbitrary
column9: advocating for his release and compensation. This case has drawn attention to PHP's controversial practices amidst its significant role in Cameroon’s banana export sector​.

column1: The land titles 328 and 329 in Moungo
column2: covering 743 hectares
column3: have been a source of conflict for Plantations du Haut Penja (PHP) for several years. The French company Compagnie Fruitière
column4: which manages PHP
column5: has occupied and exploited these lands for banana cultivation for decades. However
column6: the company faced legal challenges related to these titles. In 2011
column7: a court ruling ordered that the titles be returned to the local communities of Mouatchom
column8: Loum
column9: Bona Olo
column10: and Bona Oho. Despite PHP's appeals
column11: the Cameroonian Supreme Court upheld the decision in 2018
column12: rejecting the company's claims to these lands. However
column13: the company continues to use the land.";Unknown;;;;;;;;Environmental degradation|Socio-economic|Cultural loss;The local community has raised concerns about the pollution of their water sources and the reduction of arable land
column14: primarily due to the extensive use of a 743-hectare area
column15: covered by land titles 328 and 329 in Moungo
column16: which has been occupied and exploited by a French company for decades. The community is experiencing collateral damage from this land use
column17: citing exploitation and negative impacts on the local economy. Additionally
column18: the use of chemicals in agricultural practices poses a serious threat to water bodies
column19: endangering both the health of the environment and the well-being of the local population.;;In 2016 the company gave away 4500 additional parcels adding to the 2250 parcels already given to  3 different associations of 5600 women;Health|Education|Roads|Capacity building|Financial support;;Health|Education|Roads|Capacity building|Financial support;"The hospital ""Hopital Saint Jean de Malte"" was constructed in Nyombe in 1997 for the benefit of local community. column8: the government accused the foundation of breaching contract as the core farm sold high volumes of staple crops to downstream customers. column1: ;;;;;;Unknown;Unknown;;Unknown;;;Yes;;;;2022-08-23#current#200#150#;LIAG Argentina cuenta con 200 puestos de trabajo de manera directa y 150 personas de forma indirecta.;Unknown;;;;;;Unknown;;;;;;;;Desde la ciudad bonaerense de Chacabuco, GDM se transformó luego de 40 años en uno de los semilleros de soja más importantes del mundo, con presencia en 15 países. Desde la empresa afirman que el 40% de las 125 millones de hectáreas sembradas con soja tiene genética de GDM. Además, vende semillas de maíz en tres países (Argentina, Estados Unidos y Brasil) y de trigo en dos (Argentina y Estados Unidos). GDM factura por año unos US$ 500 millones anuales y emplea a más de 1.200 personas, de las cuales reinvierte un 25% en Investigación y Desarrollo. CADENA DE INVERSION Los integrantes de la familia Bartolomé, propietarios del Grupo Don Mario (GDM), la empresa más destacada a nivel local e internacional en el desarrollo genético en soja y también muy bien posicionada en trigo y maíz, compraron el 100% del paquete accionario de la empresa argentina de producción agroindustrial LIAG. La operación se realizó de manera absolutamente desvinculada a GDM, y por un monto de USD 195 millones, la cual cuenta con el apoyo del Banco Rabobank que financió un importante porcentaje de la adquisición. Se trata de una de las compras más destacadas en el mundo de la agroindustria nacional.;44457;Don Mario (GDM);Argentina;Private company;https://www.donmario.com/;;Grupo Don Mario Semillas

column1: At last
column2: after three years of petitioning
column3: collecting evidence and documentation
column4: the indigenous peoples’ struggle began to yield some positive outcomes. In fact
column5: the NCIP (National Commission on Indigenous Peoples) finally confirmed that the Memorandum of Understanding (MOA)
column6: previously entered between the two companies and the local communities
column7: was based on an improper application of FPIC guidelines. Hence
column8: NCIP decided to suspend Lionheart’s Certificate of Precondition (CP)
column9: which had been issued to allow the company to carry out their operations on indigenous land.

column1: As a result
column2: Lionheart filed a motion of reconsideration as of June 1 and 16
column4: requesting NCIP to lift the order of suspension and allowing the company to resolve the issue by paying the required bond
column5: whose amount had to be decided by the affected tribes
column6: pursuant to section 23 of the 2012 FPIC guidelines.

column1: In early 2018
column2: the IPs claimed that Lionheart started operation without the Free and Prior Informed Consent (FPIC) procedures from the NCIP.

column1: On the NCIP’s en banc resolution (CEB Resolution No. 07-124.2018 Series of 2018) dated September 28
column3: Lionheart’s operation was suspended until it complies with the FPIC guidelines.

column1: Two months later
column2: Lionheart
